Thanks, Healthy Rivers Partnerships, for having
me speak tonight.

the Success of

41.88.text:

and I must say

45.13.text:
that this work has been supported by the Missouri
Department of

47.77.text:

scale.

to the Missouri

River and then to the

73.63.text:
Another
reason that I wanted to call it Farmville

75.22.text:
3.0, is that
conservation programs in the United States

78.35.text:
are not really new,
but issues around then remain, and there has

84.22.text:
been sort of
historically, three main agricultural conservation

88.91.text:
programs in
the United States and they have often come

92.77.text:
about in response to
environmental disasters such as the Dust Bowl

96.70.text:
in 1935, or kind of
renewed understanding about conservation issues

102.36.text:
such as the gulf
hypoxic zone, which I will talk more in detail

105.47.text:
about, which we
have come to understand a lot about.

109.52.text:
These programs are
incentive based, but we really do not have

113.85.text:
a lot of information
about how well they work.

116.79.text:
So the first program was really called a set-aside
program.

120.31.text:
We
paid farmers to not grow things like wheat

123.15.text:
or corn, and farmers
being astute business people just decided

127.03.text:
to grow a different
crop, which is not necessarily a very effect

131.51.text:
In 1986, the Conservation Reserve Program,
which is

137.25.text:
considered by many to be the most effective
environmental

141.36.text:
agricultural program, basically pays farmers
a small amount of

144.69.text:
money to not grow crops at all on the most
erodible land.

149.19.text:
And
that began in 1986 and it ramped up, but in

153.48.text:
more recent years as
government funding has begun to shrink, we

157.36.text:
have moved to a
different kind of program which really began

160.44.text:
in the early Bush II
years, and that is called Working Lands Conservation,

165.53.text:
and that is
where the assumption is that farmers can still

169.14.text:
grow crops on the
land, but we can do certain kinds of conservation

173.39.text:
measures that
actually can improve water quality, but again,

179.18.text:
So what we have typically done, is we have
determined the

182.23.text:
success of the program based on how much money
we spend on it,

187.35.text:
and as resources get fewer and fewer, there
is discussion about

192.93.text: are we effectively spending our money?

195.84.text:
So in 2010, the US Department Of Agriculture
increased support

200.21.text:
for these integrated conservation measures
and those run the

203.98.text:
gamut from many different things—riparian
buffer zones, terraces,

207.93.text:
so farmers can get some funds to help them
do these sorts of

211.59.text:
things—tile drains, rotational grazing,
there are all kinds of

215.90.text:
No-till lagoon crops, tillage radishes—so
this money was

219.62.text:
earmarked for certain watersheds, such as
the Grand River and

222.70.text:
other basins in the Missouri and Mississippi
that were known to

227.82.text:
provide a lot of nutrients, ultimately to
the gulf of Mexico.

So integrated farming practices on the land,
if you were to drive

255.26.text:
Things like waste lagoons that

304.86.text:
Here is a little cartoon
of hypoxia and it is also similar to eutrophication.

310.59.text:
So really what happens is nutrients, either
in the form of runoff

315.15.text:
from agricultural fields or from waste water
treatment plants or

319.52.text:
urban lands, are delivered into some kind
of river or water body,

326.64.text:
then energy in the form of sunlight, allows
algae to grow in

331.25.text:
these water bodies, and what can happen is,
if there is enough

334.72.text:
energy and excessive nutrients, then this
algal growth can get

338.12.text:
pretty far, and eventually, it blocks the
sunlight at depth and

344.76.text:
the algae that grows here, this algal matter,
begins to die and

349.14.text:
sink to the bottom and when it does, bacteria
begins to decompose

353.13.text:
it, and it consumes all the oxygen, which
the fish and other

359.87.text:
So if you cannot move away from this
zone, you are going to die.

363.53.text:
Some things can move away from that
zone, but some of the lower critters in the

368.51.text:
food chain, which
support the other food chain, perish.

374.98.text:
And the hypoxic zone is sort of a seasonal
phenomenon.

386.05.text:
So in the summertime, all this red here is
dissolved oxygen levels that are below 2 milligrams

391.37.text:
per liter, so
we have a large area, and 2 milligrams per

394.61.text:
liter, will not
sustain aquatic life.

397.46.text:
So we have a large area of really depleted
oxygen that is sometimes referred to as the

404.54.text:
In the
summer time, and this is also the time when

most nutrients are

417.89.text:
when the temperatures
cool down and there is less mobility of nutrients,

the system can

not just for us, but
